dt: {bc}a container used to remove water from a boat

et: Middle English {it}baille{/it}, from Anglo-French, bucket, from Medieval Latin {it}bajula{/it} water vessel, from feminine of Latin {it}bajulus{/it} porter, carrier
shortdef: a container used to remove water from a boat

dt: {bc}to clear (water) from a boat by dipping and throwing over the side
{bc}to clear water from by dipping and throwing

dt.t: had to start {wi}bailing{/wi} out the rowboat
You can't say he has ever {wi}bailed{/wi} when things got tough, because that's just not true.
Before the party moved elsewhere, I {wi}bailed{/wi}, exhausted.

shortdef: to clear (water) from a boat by dipping and throwing over the side —usually used with out
to clear water from by dipping and throwing —usually used with out
bail out

dt: {bc}the temporary release of a prisoner in exchange for security {dx_def}see {dxt|security||2a}{/dx_def} given for the prisoner's appearance at a later hearing

dt.t: The suspect is now out on {wi}bail{/wi}.

dt: {bc}security given for the release of a prisoner on bail

et: Middle English, custody, bail, from Anglo-French, literally, handing over, delivery, from {it}baillier{/it} to give, entrust, hand over, from Latin {it}bajulare{/it} to carry a burden, from {it}bajulus{/it} porter, carrier
shortdef: the temporary release of a prisoner in exchange for security given for the prisoner's appearance at a later hearing
security given for the release of a prisoner on bail
one who provides bail

dt: {bc}to temporarily release (a prisoner) in exchange for security {dx_def}see {dxt|security||2a}{/dx_def} given for appearance at a later hearing {bc}to release under bail {dx_def}see {dxt|bail:3||1}{/dx_def}
{bc}to procure the release of by giving bail {dx_def}see {dxt|bail:3||2}{/dx_def}

dt.t: Her lawyer {wi}bailed{/wi} her out of jail.
His parents are always {wi}bailing{/wi} him out of trouble.

shortdef: to temporarily release (a prisoner) in exchange for security given for appearance at a later hearing : to release under bail
to procure the release of by giving bail —often used with out
to help from a predicament —used with out

dt: {bc}a U-shaped strip used to support something (such as the cover of a wagon or the canopy of a small boat)
{bc}a hinged bar for holding paper against the {d_link|platen|platen} of a typewriter
{bc}a usually arched handle (as of a kettle or pail)

et: Middle English {it}beil, baile{/it}, probably from Old English {it}*begel, *bygel{/it}; akin to Middle Dutch {it}beughel{/it} iron ring, hilt guard; akin to Old English {it}būgan{/it} to bend {ma}{mat|bow|}{/ma}
shortdef: a U-shaped strip used to support something (such as the cover of a wagon or the canopy of a small boat)
a hinged bar for holding paper against the platen of a typewriter
a usually arched handle (as of a kettle or pail)

dt: {bc}to deliver (personal property) in trust to another for a special purpose and for a limited period

shortdef: to deliver (personal property) in trust to another for a special purpose and for a limited period

dt: {bc}a device for confining or separating animals

shortdef: a device for confining or separating animals

et: Middle English, "evil-doing, threat of evil, harm, destruction of life, torment, grief," going back to Old English {it}bealu{/it} (neuter), genitive {it}bealwes{/it} "evil-doing, malice, harm, destruction, torment," going back to Germanic {it}*balwa-{/it} "evil," in both active and passive aspects (whence also Old Frisian {it}bale-{/it} [in {it}balemunda{/it} "disloyal guardian"], Old Saxon {it}balu{/it} "wickedness," Middle Dutch {it}bal-{/it} [in {it}baldadich{/it} "wanton"], Old High German {it}balo, palo{/it} "evil, disaster, treachery," Old Icelandic {it}bǫl{/it} "misfortune," Gothic {it}balwa-{/it} [in {it}balwawesei{/it} "wickedness"]), noun derivative from neuter of an adjective {it}*balwa-{/it} (whence Old English {it}bealu{/it} "evil, pernicious"), going back to dialectal Indo-European {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}ol-,{/it} whence also Old Church Slavic {it}bolĭ{/it} "sick person," Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian {it}bôl{/it} "pain," Russian {it}bol'{/it}

The etymon {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}ol-{/it} is attested with certainty only in Germanic and Slavic, assuming that this comparison itself is correct. Proposed links with other Indo-European branches, as Celtic, are less convincing.
shortdef: great evil
woe, sorrow

dt: {bc}a large closely pressed package of merchandise bound and usually wrapped

et: Middle English, from Middle French, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German {it}balla{/it} ball
shortdef: a large bundle of goods; specifically : a large closely pressed package of merchandise bound and usually wrapped

dt: {bc}to abandon a harmful or difficult situation

shortdef: to parachute from an aircraft
to abandon a harmful or difficult situation; also : leave, depart
